question: Should there be a world government?

content.source_1: [United Nations official materials — The UN explicitly states it is not a world government and does not legislate for member states, indicating that mainstream global institutions reject a world-government model.]
content.source_2: [Albert Einstein’s post–World War II writings (late 1940s–1950) — Einstein publicly advocated a supranational world government to control nuclear weapons and prevent war, showing influential support for the idea.]
content.source_3: [Nick Bostrom, Superintelligence: Paths, Dangers, Strategies (2014) — Introduces the “singleton” concept, arguing that a stable, centralized global authority might be necessary to manage existential risks (e.g., advanced AI), providing a contemporary rationale for world government.]
content.source_4: [Elinor Ostrom, “Polycentric systems for coping with collective action and global environmental change” (2010) — Empirical and theoretical case for decentralized, overlapping centers of authority rather than a single global authority, challenging the need for world government.]
content.source_5: [John J. Mearsheimer, The Tragedy of Great Power Politics (2001; later editions) — Realist IR perspective contending that anarchy, power balancing, and state interests make a world government infeasible and potentially unstable.]
content.source_6: [World Federalist Movement–Institute for Global Policy — Ongoing advocacy (e.g., proposals for a UN Parliamentary Assembly) explicitly promoting steps toward democratic world federation, evidencing organized contemporary support for world government.]
